Declaration of presumed death
	Applying for declaration
		This section applies where a person who is missing—
			is thought to have died, or
			has not been known to be alive for a period of at least 7 years.
		Any person may apply to the High Court for a declaration that the missingperson is presumed to be dead.
		The court has jurisdiction to hear and determine an application under thissection only if—
			the missing person was domiciled in England and Wales on the day on whichhe or she was last known to be alive,
			the missing person had been habitually resident in England and Walesthroughout the period of 1 year ending with that day, or
			subsection (4) is satisfied.
		This subsection is satisfied if the application is made by the spouse orcivil partner of the missing person and—
			the applicant is domiciled in England and Wales on the day on which theapplication is made, or
			the applicant has been habitually resident in England and Wales throughoutthe period of 1 year ending with that day.
		The court must refuse to hear an application under this section if—
			the application is made by someone other than the missing person’s spouse,civil partner, parent, child or sibling, and
			the court considers that the applicant does not have a sufficient interestin the determination of the application.
		This section has effect subject to section 21(2).
	Making declaration
		On an application under section 1, the court must make the declaration ifit is satisfied that the missing person—
			has died, or
			has not been known to be alive for a period of at least 7 years.
		It must include in the declaration a finding as to the date and time of themissing person’s death.
		Where the court—
			is satisfied that the missing person has died, but
			is uncertain at which moment during a period the missing person died,
				the finding must be that the missing person is presumed to have died at theend of that period.
		Where the court—
			is satisfied that the missing person has not been known to be alive for aperiod of at least 7 years, but
			is not satisfied that the missing person has died,
			the finding must be that the missing person is presumed to have died at theend of the period of 7 years beginning with the day after the day on which heor she was last known to be alive.
	Effect of declaration
		A declaration under this Act is conclusive of—
			the missing person’s presumed death, and
			the date and time of the death.
		A declaration under this Act is effective against all persons and for allpurposes, including for the purposes of—
			the acquisition of an interest in any property, and
			the ending of a marriage or civil partnership to which the missing personis a party.
		But subsections (1) and (2) apply to a declaration only if—
			it has not been appealed against and the period for bringing an appeal hasended, or
			it has been appealed against and the appeal (and any further appeal) hasbeen unsuccessful.
		For the purposes of subsection (3), an appeal has been unsuccessful if—
			it has been dismissed or withdrawn, and
			any period for bringing a further appeal has ended.
	Other powers of court making declaration
		When making a declaration under this Act, the court may—
			determine any question which relates to an interest in property and arisesas a result of the declaration, and
			determine the domicile of the missing person at the time of his or herpresumed death.
		When making a declaration under this Act, the court may make such order asit considers reasonable in relation to any interest in property acquired as aresult of the declaration.
		An order under subsection (2) may direct that the value of any interest inproperty acquired as a result of the declaration is not to be recoverable byvirtue of an order made under section 7(2).
		It may, in particular, direct that the value of the interest—
			is not to be recoverable in any circumstances, or
			is not to be recoverable where conditions specified in the order are met.

Variation order
	Varying and revoking declaration
		On an application by any person, a declaration under this Act may be variedor revoked by an order of the High Court (a “variation order”).
		The court must refuse to hear an application for a variation order if itconsiders that the applicant does not have a sufficient interest in thedetermination of the application.
	Effect of variation order
		A variation order does not affect an interest in property acquired as aresult of a declaration under this Act (but see section 7).
		A variation order does not revive a marriage or civil partnership that wasbrought to an end by virtue of a declaration under this Act.
		Except as otherwise required by subsection (1) or (2)—
			where a variation order varies a declaration, subsections (1) and (2) ofsection 3 have effect in relation to the declaration as varied by the order,and
			where a variation order revokes a declaration, those subsections cease tohave effect in relation to the declaration.
		But subsection (3) applies only if—
			the variation order has not been appealed against and the period forbringing an appeal has ended, or
			the variation order has been appealed against and the appeal (and anyfurther appeal) has been unsuccessful.
		For the purposes of subsection (4), an appeal has been unsuccessful if—
			it has been dismissed or withdrawn, and
			any period for bringing a further appeal has ended.
	Other functions of court making variation order
		When making a variation order, the court may—
			determine any question which relates to an interest in property and arisesas a result of the variation order, and
			determine the domicile of the missing person at the time of his or herpresumed death.
		When making a variation order, the court must make such further order (ifany) as it considers reasonable in relation to any interest in propertyacquired as a result of the declaration varied or revoked by the order (“theoriginal declaration”) (but see subsections (3), (5) and (6)).
		The court must not make an order under subsection (2) if the applicationfor the variation order was made after the end of the period of 5 yearsbeginning with the day on which the original declaration was made, unless itconsiders that there are exceptional circumstances which make it appropriateto do so.
		In considering what order to make under subsection (2), the court must, asfar as practicable, have regard to the principles in section 8.
		An order under subsection (2) does not affect income that accrued in theperiod—
			beginning with the day on which the original declaration was made, and
			ending with the day on which the variation order was made.
		An order under subsection (2) does not affect or provide grounds tochallenge—
			a related good faith transaction, or
			an interest in property acquired under such a transaction.
		A “related good faith transaction” is a transaction under which a personacquires an interest in the property that is the subject of the order (or anypart of it) in good faith and for value from—
			a person who acquired an interest in the property (or any part of it) as aresult of the original declaration, or
			a person who acquired an interest in the property (or any part of it) froma person described in paragraph (a), whether directly or indirectly.
		Where a person has entitlement under a trust by virtue of an order undersubsection (2), the trustee is liable to that person for any loss suffered bythat person on account of any breach of trust by the trustee in theadministration or distribution of all or part of the property that is thesubject of the order.
		Subsection (8) does not apply to the extent that the trustee’s liability isrestricted under any enactment or by any provision in a deed regulating theadministration of the trust.
		In subsection (9) “enactment” includes an enactment contained in—
			an instrument made under an Act, or
			an Act or Measure of the National Assembly for Wales or an instrument madeunder such an Act or Measure.
	Principles 
		These are the principles referred to in section 7(4).
		The first principle is relevant where property (“the relevant property”) isbeing or has been administered under a trust.
		The first principle is that—
			a person who, but for section 6(1), would have an interest in the relevantproperty by virtue of a variation order, and
			a person who, but for section 6(1), would have acquired an interest in therelevant property from a person described in paragraph (a),
				should be entitled to have made over to him or her by the trustee in fullsatisfaction of that interest the things listed in subsection (4).
		Those things are—
			the interest in the relevant property or an equivalent interest in propertyrepresenting the relevant property, to the extent that such property is stillin the hands of the trustee when the variation order is made, and
			the value of the interest in the relevant property, to the extent that suchproperty has been distributed.
		The second principle is relevant where an insurer has paid a capital sum asa result of a declaration varied or revoked by a variation order.
		The second principle is that the capital sum, or any part of the capitalsum, should be repaid to the insurer if the facts in respect of which thevariation order was made justify such repayment.
		The references in subsections (5) and (6) to a capital sum do not include acapital sum distributed by way of an annuity or other periodical payment.

Further provision about declarations and orders
	Giving notice of application
		A person who makes an application under this Act for a declaration or avariation order must send to the persons specified by rules of court—
			notice of the application, and
			any other information specified by rules of court.
		An application under this Act for a declaration or a variation order mustbe advertised in accordance with rules of court.
		The court must refuse to hear an application under this Act for adeclaration or a variation order if the requirements in this section have notbeen met.
	Attorney General
		In proceedings on an application under this Act for a declaration or avariation order, the court may at any stage direct that papers relating to thematter be sent to the Attorney General.
		It may do so on the application of a party to the proceedings or withoutsuch an application being made.
		Where the Attorney General incurs costs in connection with an applicationunder this Act for a declaration or a variation order, the court may make suchorder as it considers appropriate as to the payment of the costs by parties tothe proceedings.
		Subsection (3) applies whether the costs are incurred by virtue of adirection under subsection (1), an intervention under section 11(2) orotherwise.
	Right to intervene
		The missing person’s spouse, civil partner, parent, child or sibling mayintervene in proceedings on an application under this Act for a declaration ora variation order.
		The Attorney General may intervene in such proceedings, whether or not thecourt directs papers relating to the application to be sent to the AttorneyGeneral.
		Any other person may intervene in such proceedings only with the permissionof the court.
		References in this section to intervening in proceedings include—
			arguing before the court any question in relation to the application whichthe court considers it necessary to have fully argued,
			in proceedings on an application for a declaration under this Act, seekinga determination or order under section 4, and
			in proceedings on an application for a variation order, seeking adetermination or order under section 7.
	Information 
		In proceedings on an application under this Act for a declaration or avariation order, the court may by order at any stage require a person who isnot a party to the proceedings to provide it with specified information thatit considers relevant to the question of whether the missing person is aliveor dead.
		It may do so only where it considers it necessary for the purpose ofdisposing of the proceedings.
		It may do so on the application of a party to the proceedings or withoutsuch an application being made.
		The order may not require the provision of information—
			which is permitted or required by any rule of law to be withheld on groundsof public interest immunity,
			which any person would be entitled to refuse to provide on grounds of legalprofessional privilege, or
			whose provision might incriminate the person providing it, or that person’sspouse or civil partner, of an offence.
		Before making an order under this section, the court must send notice ofits intention to make the order to any person who, in its opinion, is likelyto be affected by the order.
		The court may discharge or vary an order made under this section on anapplication made by any person who, in the opinion of the court, is affectedby it.
		In this section “specified” means specified in an order under this section.
	Insurance against claims: trustees
		If the court so directs, the trustee of a trust affected by a declarationunder this Act must as soon as reasonably practicable take out an insurancepolicy in respect of any claim which may arise by virtue of an order undersection 7(2).
		For the purposes of this section, a trust is affected by a declarationunder this Act if—
			it arises as a result of the declaration, or
			property held under the trust is affected by the declaration.
		A premium payable by the trustee in accordance with a direction under thissection may be paid out of money or other property held under the trust.
	Insurance against claims: insurers paying capital sums
		Before paying a capital sum to a person as a result of a declaration underthis Act, an insurer may require the person to take out an insurance policy inrespect of any claim which the insurer may make in the event of a variationorder being made.
		The policy must be taken out—
			in the person’s own name, and
			for the benefit of the insurer.
		Subsection (1) does not apply where the sum is paid in respect of anannuity or other periodical payment.
		In this section “insurer” means any person who provides for the payment ofa benefit on a person’s death.

Other determinations
	Other determinations about death of missing person
		No declaration which may be applied for under section 1 may be madeotherwise than under this Act.
		Where a court or tribunal makes a declaration that a missing person ispresumed to be dead (other than on an application under this Act), subsections(2) to (4) of section 2 apply to the court or tribunal as they apply to theHigh Court when it makes a declaration under this Act.
		Schedule 2 (amendment of provisions about presumption of death) has effect.
		Apart from subsections (1) to (3) and Schedule 2, nothing in the precedingprovisions of this Act affects any power or duty that a court or tribunal hasother than under this Act to determine a question relating to the death of amissing person.

Supplementary
	Power to amend periods of time
		The Secretary of State may by regulations amend this Act by increasing orreducing a period of time referred to in—
			section 1(1)(b),
			section 2(1) or (4), or
			section 7(3).
	Consequential and supplementary etc provision
		The Secretary of State may by regulations make consequential,supplementary, incidental, transitional, transitory or saving provision inrelation to any provision of this Act.
		Regulations under this section may amend, repeal or revoke an enactmentpassed or made before, or in the same Session as, this Act is passed.
		In this section “enactment” includes an enactment contained in—
			an instrument made under an Act, or
			an Act or Measure of the National Assembly for Wales or an instrument madeunder such an Act or Measure.
	Regulations 
		Regulations under this Act are to be made by statutory instrument.
		A statutory instrument containing the following regulations (whether aloneor with other provision) may not be made unless a draft of the instrument hasbeen laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament—
			regulations under section 17;
			regulations under section 18 which amend or repeal an Act (including an Actor Measure of the National Assembly for Wales).
		Any other statutory instrument containing regulations made by the Secretaryof State under this Act is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolutionof either House of Parliament.
	Interpretation 
		In this Act—
			  * “the court” means the High Court (except in section 16(2)); 
			  * “interest in property” means an interest in property of any description, including an estate in land and a right over property; 
			  * “the missing person”, in relation to a declaration under this Act or an application, determination or order made in connection with such a declaration, means the person who is or would be the subject of the declaration; 
			  * “the Registrar General” means the Registrar General for England and Wales; 
			  * “sibling” means a sibling of the full blood or the half blood; 
			  * “trustee” includes an executor, administrator or personal representative; 
			  * “variation order” has the meaning given in section 5. 
		References in this Act to a party to proceedings include a personintervening in the proceedings in accordance with section 11.
	Application to Crown
		This Act binds the Crown.
		But an application may not be made under this Act for a declaration inrespect of Her Majesty.
	Commencement 
		The following come into force on the day on which this Act is passed—
			section 9 so far as it confers a power to make rules,
			section 15(4) and Schedule 1 so far as they confer a power to makeregulations,
			sections 17 to 21,
			this section, and
			sections 23 and 24.
		Subject to subsection (1), the provisions of this Act come into force onsuch day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint.
		An order under this section must be made by statutory instrument.
		An order under this section may—
			appoint different days for different purposes, and
			include transitional, transitory or saving provision.
	Extent 
		This Act extends to England and Wales.
	Short title
		This Act may be cited as the Presumption of Death Act 2013.
